shortExplanation: a detailed investigation of the parts of something
longExplanation: The process of breaking a complex topic or substance into smaller parts in order to gain a better understanding of it.

examples.sentence: The chemical analysis of the water sample revealed high levels of lead.
Her analysis of the economic data was presented to the board.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A detailed inspection or study

antonyms.coreMeaning: The combination of components to form a connected whole

shortExplanation: a way of considering or doing something
longExplanation: A way of dealing with a situation or problem; a way of considering or handling something.

examples.sentence: The company is taking a new approach to staff management.
We need to find a fresh approach to the problem.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A particular procedure for accomplishing something

shortExplanation: a subject or specialization, or part of it
longExplanation: A region or part of a town, a country, or the world; a subject or range of activity or interest.

examples.sentence: This is a designated residential area.
His main area of research is in genetic engineering.

synonyms.coreMeaning: An area, especially part of a country or the world having definable characteristics

shortExplanation: when you decide the value or quality of something
longExplanation: The evaluation or estimation of the nature, quality, or ability of someone or something.

examples.sentence: The school uses a variety of methods for student assessment.
A detailed risk assessment is required before the project can begin.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The making of a judgment about the amount, number, or value of something

shortExplanation: accept something to be true without questioning it
longExplanation: Suppose to be the case, without proof; take or begin to have (power or responsibility).

examples.sentence: I assume you know each other.
He assumed the role of team captain.

synonyms.coreMeaning: To think of something as being true or possible

shortExplanation: an expert on a subject
longExplanation: The power or right to give orders, make decisions, and enforce obedience; a person or organization having power or control in a particular, typically political or administrative, sphere.

examples.sentence: He is a leading authority on marine biology.
The local authority is responsible for maintaining the roads.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A person who has a comprehensive and authoritative knowledge of or skill in a particular area

shortExplanation: able to be used
longExplanation: Able to be used or obtained; at someone's disposal. (Of a person) not otherwise occupied; free to do something.

examples.sentence: There are no tickets available for the show.
The manager is not available to see you right now.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Able to be reached or entered

antonyms.coreMeaning: Not able to be used or obtained; not at someone's disposal

shortExplanation: to succeed in reaching a target or aim
longExplanation: Successfully bring about or reach (a desired objective, level, or result) by effort, skill, or courage.

examples.sentence: She worked hard to achieve her goals.
The company hopes to achieve a 20% increase in sales this year.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Succeed in achieving (something that one desires and has worked for)

antonyms.coreMeaning: Be unsuccessful in achieving one's goal

shortExplanation: the process of getting something
longExplanation: The learning or developing of a skill, habit, or quality; an asset or object bought or obtained.

examples.sentence: The acquisition of a new language takes time and practice.
The company's latest acquisition is a small tech startup.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The action of buying something

shortExplanation: a method of managing the affairs of an organization
longExplanation: The process or activity of running a business, organization, etc.; the management of public affairs; government.

examples.sentence: She works in the hospital administration department.
The current administration has introduced new policies.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The process of dealing with or controlling things or people

shortExplanation: to influence or cause something to change
longExplanation: Have an effect on; make a difference to.

examples.sentence: The weather can greatly affect his mood.
The new law will affect everyone in the country.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The capacity to have an effect on the character, development, or behavior of someone or something

shortExplanation: suitable or right for a particular purpose or situation
longExplanation: Suitable or proper in the circumstances.

examples.sentence: Please wear appropriate clothing for the interview.
This is not an appropriate time to discuss the matter.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Right or appropriate for a particular person, purpose, or situation

antonyms.coreMeaning: Not suitable or proper in the circumstances

shortExplanation: the parts of a problem, situation or task
longExplanation: A particular part or feature of something.

examples.sentence: We must consider all aspects of the problem before making a decision.
The book covers various aspects of modern life.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A distinctive attribute or aspect of something

shortExplanation: an act of helping to complete a task
longExplanation: The action of helping someone with a job or task.

examples.sentence: Can I be of any assistance?
He was able to complete the project with the assistance of his colleagues.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The action of helping someone to do something

antonyms.coreMeaning: A thing that provides resistance, delay, or obstruction to something or someone

shortExplanation: something different, or a choice of something else
longExplanation: (Of one or more things) available as another possibility.

examples.sentence: We had no alternative but to cancel the event.
There are several alternative routes to the city center.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A thing that is or may be chosen

shortExplanation: the ability to get to or enter somewhere or something
longExplanation: The means or opportunity to approach or enter a place.

examples.sentence: The only access to the village is by boat.
Do you have access to the internet?

synonyms.coreMeaning: An act of going or coming in

antonyms.coreMeaning: A way out

shortExplanation: enough or barely enough
longExplanation: Satisfactory or acceptable in quality or quantity.

examples.sentence: The food was adequate but not exceptional.
He didn't have adequate time to prepare for the exam.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Enough; adequate

antonyms.coreMeaning: Lacking the quality or quantity required; insufficient for a purpose

shortExplanation: happening once a year
longExplanation: Occurring once every year.

examples.sentence: The company holds an annual conference for its employees.
The annual rainfall in this region is very low.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Happening or produced once a year or every year

shortExplanation: able to be understood, or seeming to exist
longExplanation: Clearly visible or understood; obvious. Seeming real or true, but not necessarily so.

examples.sentence: It was apparent that she was not happy with the decision.
The apparent cause of the accident was a mechanical failure.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Easily perceived or understood; clear, self-evident, or apparent

antonyms.coreMeaning: Not easy to see, hear, or understand

shortExplanation: came near to, or estimated
longExplanation: Come close or be similar to something in quality, nature, or quantity.

examples.sentence: The results of the experiment approximated the theoretical predictions.
The cost of the project can only be approximated at this stage.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Roughly calculate or judge the value, number, quantity, or extent of

shortExplanation: feelings or opinions about someone or something
longExplanation: A settled way of thinking or feeling about someone or something, typically one that is reflected in a person's behavior.

examples.sentence: Public attitudes towards the environment have changed over the years.
He has a very positive attitude to his work.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A view or judgment formed about something, not necessarily based on fact or knowledge

shortExplanation: indicated the cause of something
longExplanation: Regard something as being caused by (someone or something).

examples.sentence: The success of the project was attributed to the hard work of the team.
The painting is attributed to a famous artist.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Attribute something to (a cause)

shortExplanation: relating to school, college, study or theory
longExplanation: Relating to education and scholarship.

examples.sentence: She has a strong academic background in science.
The book is of a very academic nature.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Involving or relating to serious academic study

shortExplanation: making small changes, or becoming suitable
longExplanation: A small alteration or movement made to achieve a desired fit, appearance, or result.

examples.sentence: I made a few adjustments to the design.
The camera requires a slight adjustment of the focus.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The action or process of altering or being altered

shortExplanation: to change the form or character of something
longExplanation: Change or cause to change in character or composition, typically in a comparatively small but significant way.

examples.sentence: We had to alter our plans because of the bad weather.
The tailor can alter the suit to fit you perfectly.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Make or become different

antonyms.coreMeaning: Cause or enable (a condition or state of affairs) to continue

shortExplanation: a change made to the words of a text
longExplanation: A minor change or addition designed to improve a text, piece of legislation, etc.

examples.sentence: They proposed an amendment to the constitution.
Several amendments were made to the original contract.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The action of revising

shortExplanation: to have knowledge or be conscious of something
longExplanation: Having knowledge or perception of a situation or fact.

examples.sentence: Are you aware of the risks involved?
She was not aware that she was being watched.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Aware of and responding to one's surroundings; awake

antonyms.coreMeaning: Having no knowledge of a situation or fact

shortExplanation: a written summary of the important points of a text
longExplanation: Existing in thought or as an idea but not having a physical or concrete existence.

examples.sentence: The article provides an abstract of the research paper.
She is a painter of abstract art.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Relating to or based on mental concepts

antonyms.coreMeaning: Existing in a material or physical form; real or solid

shortExplanation: correct and without any mistakes
longExplanation: (Of information, measurements, statistics, etc.) correct in all details; exact.

examples.sentence: The report provides an accurate description of the events.
It is important to keep accurate records.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Marked by exactness and accuracy of expression or detail

antonyms.coreMeaning: Not accurate

shortExplanation: recognized, admitted the truth, or expressed thanks
longExplanation: Accept or admit the existence or truth of.

examples.sentence: She acknowledged that she had made a mistake.
He is widely acknowledged as one of the best players in the world.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Confess to be true or to be the case

shortExplanation: the total of all the parts
longExplanation: A whole formed by combining several (typically disparate) elements.

examples.sentence: The aggregate of all the donations was over $1 million.
The team's aggregate score was the highest in the competition.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Comprising the whole number or amount

shortExplanation: a share of something for a specific purpose
longExplanation: The action or process of allocating or sharing out something.

examples.sentence: The allocation of resources is a key part of project management.
The government announced the allocation of funding for new schools.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The action of sharing something out among a number of recipients

shortExplanation: gave someone a task, or sorted something into groups
longExplanation: Allocate (a job or duty).

examples.sentence: Each student was assigned a different project.
The new employee was assigned to the marketing department.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Distribute (resources or duties) for a particular purpose

shortExplanation: added or fixed something to something else
longExplanation: Joined or fastened to something.

examples.sentence: Please find the document attached to this email.
The house has an attached garage.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Brought together or into contact so that a real or notional link is established

antonyms.coreMeaning: Separate or disconnected

shortExplanation: writer
longExplanation: A writer of a book, article, or report.

examples.sentence: He is the author of several best-selling novels.
The author of the report will present her findings tomorrow.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A person who has written a particular text

shortExplanation: modification to suit new conditions or environment
longExplanation: The action or process of adapting or being adapted.

examples.sentence: The film is an adaptation of a classic novel.
Adaptation to a new environment can be a difficult process.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The action of modifying something

shortExplanation: people or living things that are fully grown or developed
longExplanation: A person who is fully grown or developed.

examples.sentence: The film is suitable for both adults and children.
Adults are responsible for their own actions.

synonyms.coreMeaning: An adult

antonyms.coreMeaning: A young human being below the age of puberty or below the legal age of majority

shortExplanation: to publicly recommend or support something
longExplanation: Publicly recommend or support.

examples.sentence: He is a strong advocate for environmental protection.
She advocates for a healthier lifestyle.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Give assistance to, especially financially; enable to function or act

antonyms.coreMeaning: Actively resist or refuse to comply with (a person or a system)

shortExplanation: to help or support
longExplanation: Help, typically of a practical nature.

examples.sentence: The organization provides humanitarian aid to developing countries.
He came to my aid when I was in trouble.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The action of helping someone to do something

antonyms.coreMeaning: A thing that provides resistance, delay, or obstruction to something or someone

shortExplanation: to leave forever, or to stop something in progress
longExplanation: Cease to support or look after (someone); desert. Give up completely (a course of action, a practice, or a way of thinking).

examples.sentence: They had to abandon the sinking ship.
The project was abandoned due to lack of funding.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Abandon (a person, cause, or organization) in a way considered disloyal or treacherous

shortExplanation: went or came with someone or something
longExplanation: Go somewhere with (someone) as a companion or escort.

examples.sentence: The president was accompanied by his wife.
The text is accompanied by a series of illustrations.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Accompany (someone or something) somewhere, especially for protection or security, or as a mark of rank

shortExplanation: collection or process of collecting
longExplanation: The acquisition or gradual gathering of something.

examples.sentence: The accumulation of wealth is his main goal in life.
The accumulation of snow on the roof is becoming dangerous.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The action or process of collecting someone or something

shortExplanation: not clear, or having two or more possible interpretations
longExplanation: Open to more than one interpretation; having a double meaning.

examples.sentence: The question is ambiguous and can be interpreted in different ways.
His reply was ambiguous, and I'm not sure if he agreed or not.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Not easy to see, hear, or understand

antonyms.coreMeaning: Easy to perceive, understand, or interpret

shortExplanation: supplementary material at the end of a book
longExplanation: A section or table of additional matter at the end of a book or document.

examples.sentence: More detailed information can be found in the appendix.
The book includes an appendix with a list of all the sources cited.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A thing added to something else in order to complete or enhance it

shortExplanation: recognition of value, or expression of thanks
longExplanation: Recognition and enjoyment of the good qualities of someone or something.

examples.sentence: She has a deep appreciation for classical music.
He showed his appreciation by sending a thank-you card.

synonyms.coreMeaning: The quality of being thankful; readiness to show appreciation for and to return kindness

shortExplanation: based on chance rather than reason
longExplanation: Based on random choice or personal whim, rather than any reason or system.

examples.sentence: The choice of winner seemed completely arbitrary.
The rules are arbitrary and unfair.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Made, done, or happening without method or conscious decision

antonyms.coreMeaning: Done or acting according to a fixed plan or system; methodical

shortExplanation: without need for help, or without thinking
longExplanation: (With reference to a device or process) by itself with little or no direct human control.

examples.sentence: The lights turn on automatically when someone enters the room.
He reacted automatically to the loud noise.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Without conscious thought; by natural instinct

antonyms.coreMeaning: By hand rather than automatically or electronically

shortExplanation: adjustment, agreement, or living place
longExplanation: A room, group of rooms, or building in which someone may live or stay.

examples.sentence: The hotel provides accommodation for over 200 guests.
They made an accommodation to the new rules.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A place in which someone lives or stays temporarily

shortExplanation: similar or comparable in some ways
longExplanation: Comparable in certain respects, typically in a way that makes clearer the nature of the things compared.

examples.sentence: The human brain is analogous to a computer.
The two situations are not analogous.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Resembling without being identical

antonyms.coreMeaning: Not alike; different

shortExplanation: expected something to happen
longExplanation: Regard as probable; expect or predict.

examples.sentence: The company anticipated a rise in sales.
The results were better than we had anticipated.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Regard (something) as likely to happen

antonyms.coreMeaning: Not expected or predicted

shortExplanation: promise or confidence
longExplanation: A positive declaration intended to give confidence; a promise.

examples.sentence: He gave me his assurance that he would be there.
She has a quiet assurance about her own abilities.

synonyms.coreMeaning: A declaration or assurance that one will do a particular thing or that a particular thing will happen

shortExplanation: achieved or gained by effort
longExplanation: Succeed in achieving (something that one desires and has worked for).

examples.sentence: She attained her goal of becoming a doctor.
He has attained a high level of proficiency in the language.

synonyms.coreMeaning: Successfully bring about or reach (a desired objective, level, or result) by effort, skill, or courage

shortExplanation: next to, near, or touching
longExplanation: Next to or adjoining something else.

examples.sentence: They live in the adjacent house.
The two shapes are adjacent to each other.

synonyms.coreMeaning: In a position that is beside (someone or something)

shortExplanation: although, even though
longExplanation: Though.

examples.sentence: He was making progress, albeit slowly.
It was an interesting job, albeit a stressful one.

synonyms.coreMeaning: In spite of the fact that; even though

shortExplanation: a regular meeting of people, or putting parts together
longExplanation: A group of people gathered together in one place for a common purpose. The action of fitting together the component parts of a machine or other object.

examples.sentence: There is a school assembly every morning.
The assembly of the new furniture took several hours.

synonyms.coreMeaning: An occasion when people come together to discuss or decide something
